name: Jollof_Rice
description: Very popular West African rice dish, cooked in a sauce based on tomatoes, bell peppers, onions, and spices.
recipe: Prepare a sauce base by blending tomatoes, bell peppers, onions, and chilies.
Sauté sliced onions in oil, add tomato paste, then the blended sauce and spices (thyme, curry, bay leaf, bouillon cube).
Let the sauce simmer to reduce.
Add the rice (pre-washed) to the sauce, mix well.
Add enough broth or water just to cover the rice.
Cover tightly and let it cook over very low heat until the rice is done and has absorbed all the sauce.

name: Fufu
description: A compact and elastic dough or ball made from boiled and pounded tubers (cassava, yam, plantain) or diluted flours (corn, cassava). Served as a main accompaniment for sauces.
recipe: (Traditional version) Peel, wash, and cut the tubers (e.g., cassava and plantains).
Boil them until tender.
Drain and pound vigorously in a mortar until a smooth and elastic dough is obtained, adding a little water if necessary.
(Flour version) Mix the flour (e.g., cassava or corn flour) with cold water.
Bring water to a boil, pour in the mixed flour/water and stir constantly with a wooden spatula over the heat until the dough thickens, becomes translucent, and pulls away from the sides.

name: Ndolè
description: A Cameroonian dish based on bitter leaves (ndolè), peanut paste, and often garnished with shrimp, smoked fish, or meat.
recipe: Boil the ndolè leaves (fresh or dried) several times to remove bitterness, then drain and chop them.
Cook the meat or smoked fish. Reserve the broth.
Blend raw peanuts with garlic, onions, and a little water to obtain a paste.
Sauté sliced onions in oil.
Add the peanut paste and a little broth, cook for a few minutes, stirring.
Stir in the chopped ndolè leaves.
Add the meat/fish and shrimp.
Simmer over low heat for about 30-45 minutes until the sauce thickens.

name: Thieboudienne
description: Senegal's national dish, it is a fish and rice dish cooked in a rich tomato sauce with various vegetables (cabbage, carrot, cassava, eggplant, okra...).
recipe: Prepare a stuffing ("Rof") with chili, garlic, parsley, pepper, bouillon cube, and stuff pieces of fish (often thiof).
Fry the stuffed fish in oil, then set it aside.
In the same oil, sauté onions, garlic, then add tomato paste and let it "brown".
Add water, vegetables cut into large pieces, the fried fish, and spices (bay leaf, nététou - if used).
Let simmer until the vegetables and fish are cooked.
Remove the fish and vegetables.
Add the rice (often broken rice) to the remaining broth and let it steam until completely absorbed.
Serve the rice topped with the vegetables and fish.

name: Egusi_Soup
description: A thick Nigerian soup made with ground melon seeds (egusi), leafy vegetables (spinach, bitter leaves...), palm oil, and various types of meat and fish.
recipe: Grind the egusi seeds and form a paste with a little water or blended onion.
Heat the palm oil, fry the egusi paste in small balls or by stirring (lump or fried method).
Add the meat broth, pre-cooked meat and fish, ground crayfish, chili, and seasonings (bouillon cube, iru/dawadawa - if used).
Let simmer for 15-20 minutes.
Add the leafy vegetables (e.g., spinach or Ugu) and cook for another 5 minutes.

name: Attieke
description: Fermented cassava semolina, steamed. A popular accompaniment in Côte d'Ivoire, often served with grilled fish or chicken and a tomato-onion sauce.
recipe: (Traditional) Grate cassava, let it ferment for a few days, press it to extract water, dry it, "granulate" it by hand, then steam it.
(Quick version - dry/pre-cooked attiéké) Rehydrate the dry attiéké with a little salted water and a drizzle of oil.
Separate grains by hand or with a fork.
Steam (in a couscoussier or microwave) for 5-10 minutes until hot and light.

name: Banku_and_Tilapia
description: A popular Ghanaian dish consisting of Banku (fermented corn and cassava dough) served with grilled Tilapia and a chili sauce (shito) or a tomato-onion sauce.
recipe: (Banku) Mix the fermented corn dough and cassava dough (or flours) with salted water.
Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly with a wooden spatula until the mixture thickens and becomes a smooth, cooked dough.
Form into balls.
(Tilapia) Clean, scale, and score the fish.
Marinate the fish with a spice blend (ginger, garlic, onion, chili, salt).
Grill the fish on the barbecue, in the oven, or in a pan until well cooked.
Serve the Banku with the grilled Tilapia and a chili/tomato sauce.

name: Ewedu_Soup
description: A viscous Nigerian soup based on jute leaves (Ewedu), typically served by the Yorubas with Gbegiri (bean soup) and Amala.
recipe: Wash the Ewedu leaves and strip them from the stems.
Boil them in a little water with a bit of potash (kaun) to tenderize (optional).
Traditionally, mash the leaves with a special small broom (Ijabe) until a slimy texture is achieved. (Modern alternative: blend very briefly).
Add ground crayfish, Iru (fermented locust bean), and a bouillon cube.
Simmer for a few minutes (do not overcook to preserve the green color).

name: Kedjenou
description: An Ivorian stew (chicken or guinea fowl) cooked by steaming in a terracotta pot (canari) or an airtight cocotte, with vegetables (onions, tomatoes, eggplants) and little to no water.
recipe: Cut the chicken into pieces.
Chop onions, tomatoes, garlic, ginger, and chili. Dice the eggplants.
Put all ingredients (chicken, vegetables, spices - thyme, bay leaf) into a cocotte or a heavy pot.
Add a very small amount of water or oil (the vegetables will release their juice).
Cover tightly (traditionally with banana leaves, otherwise a heavy lid or aluminum foil).
Cook over very low heat for 45 min to 1h, shaking the pot occasionally (without opening it) to prevent sticking.

name: Saka_saka
description: A stew made from pounded cassava leaves, simmered in palm oil with smoked fish, meat, onions, and sometimes peanut butter or coconut milk.
recipe: Wash and pound the cassava leaves very finely (or use already pounded frozen leaves).
Put the pounded leaves in a pot with a little water and boil them for a long time (at least 1 hour) to remove toxicity and tenderize them.
Add the onions, garlic, smoked fish (or pre-cooked meat), and palm oil.
Continue simmering over low heat for another 1 to 2 hours, stirring regularly.
(Optional) Add peanut butter or coconut milk towards the end to thicken.
Season with salt, chili, and bouillon cube.

name: Ugali
description: A thick porridge made from maize flour (cornmeal) or other grains, commonly consumed in East Africa. It's a staple food similar to polenta or grits.
recipe: Bring water to a boil in a pot with a pinch of salt.
Gradually add maize flour while stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Continue stirring and cooking until the mixture thickens to a smooth consistency.
Cook for 10-15 minutes, stirring regularly.
Remove from heat and let it cool slightly before serving.

name: Matoke
description: Steamed green bananas (plantains) cooked with onions, tomatoes, and spices. A popular dish in Uganda and surrounding regions.
recipe: Peel and cut the green bananas into pieces.
Dice onions and tomatoes.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until translucent.
Add garlic, ginger, and spices, cook for 1 minute.
Add bananas and tomatoes, season with salt and pepper.
Cover and steam for 20-25 minutes until tender, stirring occasionally.

name: Nyama_Choma
description: Grilled or roasted meat, usually goat or beef, seasoned with simple spices and often served with ugali and vegetables.
recipe: Cut meat into large pieces, season with salt, pepper, and garlic.
Let marinate for at least 2 hours.
Grill over medium-high heat until well-browned outside and cooked inside.
Serve hot with ugali, chapati, and spicy tomato-onion sauce.

name: Sadza
description: A thick porridge made from maize meal, similar to ugali, commonly eaten in Zimbabwe and neighboring countries.
recipe: Boil water with salt in a large pot.
Gradually add maize meal while stirring continuously.
Cook for 15-20 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent burning.
The mixture should be thick and smooth.
Serve hot with meat or vegetable stews.

name: Pap_et_Chakalaka
description: A South African dish consisting of a thick cornmeal porridge (pap) served with a spicy vegetable relish (chakalaka).
recipe: Cook pap by boiling water and adding maize meal gradually, stirring constantly for 20 minutes.
For chakalaka: sauté onions in oil, add vegetables and spices, cook for 15 minutes.
Serve pap topped with hot chakalaka.

name: Seswaa
description: Botswanian dish of slowly cooked, shredded meat (usually beef or goat) that's seasoned and served with pap or rice.
recipe: Season meat with salt and place in a pot with bay leaves and onions.
Add water to barely cover meat.
Cook very slowly for 4-6 hours until meat falls apart easily.
Shred the meat using forks, strain the cooking liquid.
Serve shredded meat with pap or rice.

name: Injera_avec_Doro_Wat
description: Ethiopian dish consisting of injera (fermented teff flatbread) served with doro wat (spicy chicken stew).
recipe: Prepare injera by fermenting teff batter for 2-3 days, then cook on griddle.
For doro wat: brown chicken, make spiced sauce with berbere, simmer 45 minutes.
Boil eggs until hard, add to stew.
Serve injera with doro wat and boiled eggs.

name: Bunny_Chow
description: South African Indian dish consisting of curry served in a hollowed-out loaf of white bread, originally created by the Indian community.
recipe: Cook curry with meat, spices, onions, and tomatoes for 45 minutes.
Hollow out white bread loaf, leaving thick crust.
Pour hot curry into bread bowl.
Serve immediately while curry is hot.

name: Boerewors
description: Traditional South African farmer's sausage made from beef, lamb, and pork, grilled over open flames.
recipe: Mix ground meats with spices and vinegar.
Stuff into natural casings to form thick sausages.
Grill over open coals, turning frequently for 15-20 minutes.
Serve with pap and boerewors sauce.

name: Birk_a_l'oeuf
description: Algerian traditional breakfast bread with egg, similar to shakshuka but in bread form, seasoned with herbs and spices.
recipe: Sauté vegetables with spices until soft.
Make wells in the mixture and crack eggs into them.
Cover and cook until eggs set.
Serve hot with bread or pita.

name: Liboke_de_poisson
description: Congolese fish dish cooked in banana leaves, imparting unique flavor and aroma to the steamed fish.
recipe: Prepare marinade with spices and herbs.
Stuff fish with marinade.
Wrap in banana leaves like a package.
Steam for 45-60 minutes until fish is cooked.
Serve directly in the banana leaf wrapper.

name: Chorba_algerian
description: Algerian soup with meat, vegetables, and spices, often served during Ramadan. Rich and aromatic.
recipe: Brown meat with onions and spices.
Add vegetables and chickpeas, simmer with water.
Add vermicelli and fresh herbs.
Cook for 30 minutes, serve hot.

name: Kwanga
description: Congolese staple food made from fermented cassava, steamed and served as a thick, gelatinous bread.
recipe: Soak cassava for 7-14 days for fermentation.
Peel and grind into paste, drain excess water.
Steam for 60 minutes until compact.
Serve hot or at room temperature.

name: Tajine
description: Traditional North African dish cooked in a tajine pot, combining meat, vegetables, and aromatic spices.
recipe: Brown meat in tajine pot.
Add vegetables, spices, and aromatics.
Cover and slow-cook for 1-2 hours.
Adjust seasoning and serve with couscous.

name: Banku_et_Tilapia
description: Ghanaian dish of fermented corn and cassava dough (banku) served with grilled tilapia fish and spicy sauce.
recipe: Prepare banku by fermenting and cooking corn-cassava mixture.
Grill tilapia with spice rub until well-cooked.
Serve banku with grilled fish and hot sauce.
